civil_law_data.description: An agreement is valid only if both parties give consent freely, without coercion, fraud, undue influence, or misrepresentation.
civil_law_data.layman_terms: A contract is only valid if you agree willingly without being forced or tricked.

civil_law_data.description: A valid contract must involve consideration, meaning something of value must be exchanged between parties.
civil_law_data.layman_terms: A deal works only if both sides give something valuable in return.

civil_law_data.description: Property can only be transferred by a registered instrument if the value is above ₹100.
civil_law_data.layman_terms: Land or house transfers must be done through proper legal documents if the value is more than ₹100.

civil_law_data.description: If a person has taken possession of property in part performance of a contract, the transferor cannot deny the transfer later.
civil_law_data.layman_terms: If you’ve moved into a property after an agreement, the seller cannot back out later.

civil_law_data.law: Law of Torts (Common Law in India)
civil_law_data.description: Failure to take reasonable care, resulting in harm to another person.
civil_law_data.layman_terms: If someone is careless and you get harmed, you can claim damages.

civil_law_data.law: Law of Torts (Common Law in India)
civil_law_data.description: Publishing false statements that harm another person’s reputation.
civil_law_data.layman_terms: Spreading lies about someone that damage their image is punishable.

civil_law_data.description: The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or equal protection of the laws.
civil_law_data.layman_terms: Everyone is equal in the eyes of the law, no special treatment.

civil_law_data.description: Individuals can directly approach the Supreme Court for enforcement of fundamental rights.
civil_law_data.layman_terms: You can go straight to the Supreme Court if your rights are violated.

civil_law_data.description: A matter already decided by a competent court cannot be re-litigated between the same parties.
civil_law_data.layman_terms: If a court has already given judgment, you can’t file the same case again.

civil_law_data.description: The court can grant a temporary injunction to maintain the status quo until the case is resolved.
civil_law_data.layman_terms: The court can order things to stay as they are until the case ends.

civil_law_data.description: The process by which a decree passed by the court is implemented or enforced.
civil_law_data.layman_terms: If you win a case, this is how the judgment is carried out in real life.

civil_law_data.definition: The legal process through which a person assumes the parenting of another, usually a child, transferring all rights and responsibilities.
civil_law_data.layman_example: When a couple legally adopts a child, that child becomes their lawful son or daughter.

civil_law_data.definition: A written statement confirmed by oath or affirmation, used as evidence in court.
civil_law_data.layman_example: If someone wants to prove their age, they may submit an affidavit declaring their date of birth.

civil_law_data.definition: A court-ordered allowance a spouse pays to the other after separation or divorce for maintenance.
civil_law_data.layman_example: After divorce, the husband may be ordered to pay monthly alimony to support his wife.

civil_law_data.definition: A legal status when an individual or company cannot repay debts.
civil_law_data.layman_example: If a business owner owes too much money and cannot pay, they may be declared bankrupt by the court.

civil_law_data.definition: A sum of money awarded by a court to compensate for loss or injury.
civil_law_data.layman_example: If a shopkeeper sells spoiled food and it makes someone sick, they may have to pay damages.

civil_law_data.definition: A formal expression of an adjudication by a civil court conclusively determining the rights of the parties.
civil_law_data.layman_example: When the court orders a landlord to return deposit money to a tenant, that is a decree.

civil_law_data.definition: The legal removal of a tenant from rented property.
civil_law_data.layman_example: If a tenant refuses to pay rent for months, the landlord can get a court order for eviction.

civil_law_data.reference: Hindu Succession Act, 1956 / Indian Succession Act
civil_law_data.definition: A person legally entitled to inherit property or title after someone’s death.
civil_law_data.layman_example: When a father dies without a will, his son or daughter becomes the legal heir.

civil_law_data.definition: The final decision given by a court after considering evidence and arguments.
civil_law_data.layman_example: The judge delivered a judgment ordering the company to pay compensation.

civil_law_data.definition: Failure to take proper care in doing something, causing damage or injury.
civil_law_data.layman_example: If a hospital does not sterilize equipment properly and a patient gets infected, that is negligence.

civil_law_data.definition: The legal right of possessing, using, and disposing of something.
civil_law_data.layman_example: If you buy a house and register it, you gain full ownership rights.

civil_law_data.definition: A person who brings a legal action against another in a civil court.
civil_law_data.layman_example: If Ramesh sues his neighbor for damaging his wall, Ramesh is the plaintiff.

civil_law_data.reference: Hindu Succession Act, 1956 / Indian Succession Act
civil_law_data.definition: The process by which the property of a deceased person is transferred to heirs.
civil_law_data.layman_example: If a man dies without a will, his wife and children get his property by succession.

civil_law_data.definition: A legal document where a person declares how their property should be distributed after death.
civil_law_data.layman_example: A father may write a will leaving his land to his daughter.
